content.description:
This route is located on the west side of Castle Rock and is the second bolted route on the west side gully.  The start is in a group of manhogany trees.

This route consists of three pitches of 5.7-5.8 face climbing that is well protected.  Nothing too exicting,  but a fun outing to the top of the formation.  Rap the route with a single 60M.
The route feels like 5.9+ with no scary crux moves.
content.protection: Quickdraws with chain anchors at the top.
content.location: Start at the highest point in the gully past a huge chockstone. This is a new route to the left of Get Your Fixe.

content.description: This route is located to the left of the start of Zinger.  The need for some trad gear makes this route interesting.  Follow a few bolts and place gear in the thin cracks until you hit an anchor.  A fun outing...
content.protection: Draws, nuts and a few small cams...

content.description: The bolted line left of "Honeymoon in Almo." Fun and varied climbing with good rests in between moves.

An amazing splitter crack on the upper headwall, hard to miss walking up.

Climb the crack, build and anchor then rap a route in the hostess gully or walk off and downclimb into the Crack House.
content.protection:
Finger sized pieces are important blue tcu size to .5 camalot.

Anchor could be bigger pieces 3 or 4 camalot, or nuts and medium cams in a spot higher with more rope drag.
content.location:
This is the obvious right to left arching crack that splits the upper headwall above Patina Atoll.

3rd classing up the gully below Numbshall and El Castleton seems a good way to approach.

content.description: Follow the bolt line up the obvious slab, step across the top of the large flake and continue up steeper easy patina to the anchors.
content.location: This route is essentially an alternate safer and more fun approach pitch for El Castleton and all the new routes further to the left.  Start on the slab just left of the staging area of Red Rib.  You can also climb the crack just to the left to the top of the flake and follow the bolts to the anchors to make the route 5.7.  The anchors provide an easy way off the large slab below El Castleton instead of having to down climb around the large chockstone in the gully. Single rope rappel to the ground.

content.description:
Red Rib is a long, beautiful, single pitch route (~200 feet--you'll need two ropes to descend safely) up the SW ridge of Castle Rock. Great position and good exposure are it's strongest points. The crux is right off the ground but the climbing remains interesting and in the 5.9/10- range for most of the first ~150'. From here, it's an easier romp to the anchors.

This route is a full 60 meter rope length.
content.protection: All bolts(don't remember the count for this long route but probably in the range of 14-16).  Rap anchors at the top.  2-60 meter ropes to rap straight down to the ground.
content.location:
The far right side of the

Southwest Side

of

Castle Rock

, it heads up the obvious rib just past the left side of the South Face.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Flakes and cracks for 120'.

Pitch 2: Crack in right-facing corner.

This incredible and bizarre route starts with a ramp to an angled dihedral and then heads up to a lip edge where the fun begins.  Puzzle through a continuous series of fascinating crux moves along the lip of a left-leaning rib, figuring out when it's best to move on top of the lip and when it's best to hang below it.  This rib lip area has scattered patina plates with a lot of blank sections.  Standing above the lip tends to be blank for hands.  Near it's end, exit right and head up to an easy crack section and finish with a thin slab/face move.
content.protection: Small rack of gear to 1.5" and long runners.  Can sling horns down low.  Bolts at the very start, along the crux section and for the top face move (probably no more than 8 total).  Bolt anchors at the top.
content.location: Far left side of the Southwest Side, just before you reach the mouth of the gully going N/NE (Hostess Gully).  The start is right of a large dihedral and just left of a narrow corner with a small roof above it.

content.description:
An obvious crack feature that doesn't have many crack moves on it.  Stem and puzzle your way to the chains. Engaging!

Pitch 2 is bolted climbing.
content.location: A short boulder at the base of a crack with a comfy belay marks the spot.

content.description: Next line left of Red Rib, chimney up to first bolt or climb up slab to the left and into gully below first bolt. Not as traveled as Red Rib but worth the while.
content.protection: Mostly bolts with some gear placement (00 to 1") in the easier sections. I placed three cams. Chain anchors. Two 60M ropes.
content.location: Just left of Red Rib. Rap into gully. I got my rope stuck here before so I pulled ropes up high and downclimbed the rest.

content.description: Excellent route well protected and recommended.  A wee-bit hairy getting to the first bolt so be careful and nothing bad about the climb unless you do it on a hot afternoon in the summer!
content.protection: Climb past many bolts to fixed chain anchors on top of both pitches.  The first bolt is kinda hard to spot and a little high up.  Rappel down "Heaven & Earth" with two ropes, next route to the left and with its own anchors on the very top of the wall.
content.location: This is the fourth climb (from the top) on the right wall in Hostess gully.  Begins with some easy slab for only about 7 feet to a small bulge/roof with the first bolt just over the bulge.  Do not confuse with "Heaven & Earth" climb to its left.

content.description:
A safe route with a roof pull down low (on surprisingly tricky holds). Above is more fun, classic Hostess Gully goodness. Bolted anchor

Pitch 2 is a 12c I haven't attempted.
content.location: Left of the crack "One for Matt"that starts with a brief scramble up a slab apron.

content.description:
The route is the highest route in the gully on the west side of Castle Rock.  Approach from the south side trails.  This one is a real gem!!!

Follow a clean plate of patina with very thin edges.  Hard mantles, crimping, and high steps lead up and left to a set of anchors.  One of the best routes on the west side.
content.protection: Draws and maybe a small cam before the first bolt...

content.description: This route is located to the left of Zinger and Twinkie on the west side of Castle Rock.  Face climb straight up the face on thin crimps to the anchor.  You will see a small arch above you.  May be easy for the grade.

climbs.name: Get Your Fixe
climbs.fa: Mike Engle, Jack Brennan, Chris Barnes

content.description: From the belay anchors at the start of 13b, stem up to the bolt line that starts deeper in the gully. Follow the bolt line to a really fun finish high on the wall.
content.location: From top anchors of Slab Happy, 4th class across the low angle slab to top of the gully below the Red Rib Wall.  Route starts at the chain anchors in the gully and is the bolt line left of 13b.  With one 60 meter rope you can rappel to the anchors at the top of the first pitch of 13b. A second single rope rappel gets you back to the start of the climb.  Alternately, a 70 meter rope just gets you back to the start of the climb from the top anchors of Get Your Fixe.  From the base of the climb, one rappel or a 4th class stroll gets you back to the anchors of Slab Happy.  From there one 60 meter rope rappel takes back to the ground.

content.description:
This is one of the first routes on the west side gully on Castle Rock. There are 3 pitches with each being ~ 100 ft long. The 3rd pitch leads left to join the 3rd and last fixed anchor on Zinger. A harder variation for the 3rd pitch (Fruit Filling - 5.10c) goes straight up the bare granite face above the 2nd anchor and into a wee crack and leaning corner that require gear.

The first pitch angles up and right through two small roofs. The 2nd pitch is easy face climbing on granite.  The 3rd pitch arcs left from the 2nd anchor to join the 3rd and last anchor on Zinger.

Rap x3 with one 60M rope.

This is a 3rd pitch variation to Fruit Pie 5.8.  The crux is the face climbing before the crack.  The crack climbing is in the 5.8-5.9 range and leads to the top.  Gear may be needed for the top.  Rap Zinger with one rope to get down. An enjoyable route with some loose rock on easy terrian.
content.protection: Draws and a light rack to 1.5"

content.description: Find a way up to the lone bolt and start of the obvious left trending crack line.  The original line starts below the chockstone following a left trending line of good climbing up to the first bolt.  Alternatively, some people either start from the top of the chockstone and climb straight up on not so good rock or follow a line of unprotected edges coming in from the left.  After clipping the bolt, pull into the crack and follow it's elegant arching line until near the top where you jog up and a little right to the anchors.
content.location: Obvious arching crack line left of Red Rib and Numbshull.  From the Red Rib staging area, approach either by scrambling to the top of the flake and into the deep gully at the base of the wall and boulder over the chockstone to the start of the roped climbing or use Slab Happy (5.9) as an approach pitch.  From the anchors on Slab Happy it is an easy 4th class stroll over the gully at the start of El Castleton.  Two rope rappel (or one 70 meter rappel) to the anchors of Slab Happy and then one more rappel to ground.

content.description: Early crux. Technical start to a roof pull, the rest of the route is probably 5.9. Long and similar quality to redtail.
content.protection: 17? a lot. Trail a rope for the rap, I would say 2 70's

content.description: Mixed route with two bolts near the ground then work your way up intermittent cracks keeping an eye out left for the last bolt on a nice looking face. Climb past the bolt to the anchors.
content.location: Start right of 13b.  2 ropes from the anchors back to the start of the climb or one rope to the midway anchors on 13b. Then a second one rope rappel back to the base.

content.description: Fun climb on featured rock. Runout in places. Supplemental gear possible. Rap with 2 ropes. Pull rope from boulder away from cliff base
content.protection: 12 bolts. Can be supplemented with nuts +/- small cams. Chain anchors.
content.location: 15' left of Fruit Pie. Ends at 2nd set of anchors for Fruit Pie.

content.description:
Arete climbing at its best!

This beautiful feature holds a series of cryptic edges and blunt arete pulling. Make your way up through some sequential crimps until you're forced up onto the juggy headwall and, bam, you're home free.
content.location: Head up gulley above start of Red Rib until you get to obvious arete

content.description: Start on the large boulder for Honeymoon in Almo. The first crux (5.9/10) is pulling over the small roof at the second bolt. The route curves left until a second small roof, then moves back slightly right. A small cam is nice for protecting the roof move since you're 15 feet out from the last bolt; although the move isn't too difficult. Climb the smooth friction face above (5.10a) to a bolt and to the chains. Rope drag can be a bit of a problem. Sporty bolt placements. From the chains a 70 M rope will just make it to the starting boulder (with rope stretch). 60 M will require a little down climbing.
content.protection: Draws and maybe a small cam.
content.location: Near the top of the Hostess Gully between "Honeymoon in Almo" and "Between Heaven and Earth".

content.description:
A long sport climb just left of It Takes Two.

Start out with a couple easy slab moves to a small roof/bulge with a bolt. Continue straight up on perfect rock for another 100' to a bolted anchor. Rap with two ropes.
content.location: Between Honeymoon in Almo and It Takes Two, this route is the second route from the top of the Hostess Gully.

content.description: Follow the bolt line through 2 overlaps (5.9) to a small stance about 2/3 the way up the wall.  Use the optional belay or continue up the bolt line (5.7) to the top anchors.
content.location: From top anchors of Slab Happy, 4th class across the low angle slab to top of the gully below the Red Rib Wall.  Route starts at the chain anchors in the gully.  One 60 meter rope in two rappels get back to the start of the climb.  One rappel or 4th class stroll gets you back to the anchors of Slab Happy.  From there one 60 meter rope rappel takes back to the ground.
